image.altText: Chau with his mother-in-law, wife Trang and son Daniel.

title.children: 'She cannot wait to see her husband again': New hopes for Australian detained in Vietnam, after PM's visit

image.altText: A close-up of a dingo looking into the camera

items.synopsis: A dingo expert says the lure of food at a campground and breeding season behaviour could be factors behind recent unprovoked attacks.

title.children: Dingo 'humanely destroyed' after attacks on children in Karijini National Park

image.altText: A wide shot of iron ore being loaded onto a ship in Port Hedland.

items.synopsis: Fair Work Ombudsman Sandra Parker says her office will investigate whether BHP was negligent in failing to identify if it was underpaying workers over a 13-year period.

title.children: Investigation into whether BHP underpayments due to 'neglect' launched by Fair Work Ombudsman

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: There is one issue that stands head and shoulders above the rest as Philip Lowe's greatest threat in the battle to control inflation, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The property market rebound could see us heading into uncharted and dangerous territory

items.synopsis: The construction industry insolvency crisis is sweeping the nation, and it's devastating for both consumers and builders. So what can be done about it?

title.children: Builders go bust in record numbers leaving thousands of Australian home owners in the lurch

image.altText: rfds transport patient

items.synopsis: A 13-year-old boy dies three days after a fire tore through a home in Geraldton in Western Australia's Midwest.

title.children: Boy dead, two still critical as Geraldton house fire investigation continues

image.altText: A small marsupial eating some food.

items.synopsis: Rapid evolution in protected havens is stripping threatened native marsupials of the "street smarts" they need to survive and escape predators in the wild, new research finds.

title.children: New conservation approach flagged as endangered marsupials evolve in the wrong way

image.altText: A young man.

items.synopsis: Joel Russo, who was only months out of prison when he repeatedly raped a female jogger on the banks of Melbourne's Merri Creek is jailed for more than 20 years.

title.children: Serial rapist jailed for 'horrendous' attack on female jogger along Melbourne creek

image.altText: A close up of Angus speaking against a dark blue background.

items.synopsis: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor says Australia has higher core inflation than all of the countries in the G7. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: Fact check: Is Australia's core inflation higher than all countries in the G7?

image.altText: Two middle aged women leaning together with big smiles

items.synopsis: Ms Folbigg spent her first day of freedom since 2003 enjoying simple pleasures, like a comfortable bed and pizza, her best friend Tracy Chapman says.

title.children: Kathleen Folbigg 'has no hatred' in wake of landmark pardoning, lawyer says

image.altText: a woman lying on the green grass with a baby by her side

items.synopsis: Extensive scientific and medical evidence proved to be key to setting Kathleen Folbigg free, 20 years after she was convicted of killing her four children.

title.children: The one-in-35-million mutation and the science that set Kathleen Folbigg free

image.altText: Tasmanian petrol prices falling

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian man who used a company fuel card to buy more than $24,000 worth of fuel, some of which he onsold to friends, avoids prison — the court acknowledging his marriage breakdown caused "great upheaval" for him before the offending started.

title.children: Man uses employer's fuel card to unlawfully buy more than $20k of petrol

image.altText: A young woman standing at a cash register looks at a woman sorting her groceries in a trolley.

items.synopsis: The odds have been shortening on the Reserve Bank of Australia lifting interest rates again, and Australia's workers are once more being blamed for driving inflation, writes David Peetz.

title.children: Don't blame Australia's lowest-paid workers if interest rates rise again

image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: Economists are divided on whether interest rates will rise for the 12th time in just over year when the RBA announces its latest decision this afternoon, while Apple shares have set a new record high in the wake of the company showcasing its new products. Follow live.

title.children: Economists split on RBA rate decision, Australian share market opens lower as it awaits announcement

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just months after being roundly criticised for delivering a private briefing to a group of bankers hosted by Barrenjoey, RBA governor Philip Lowe is providing another private briefing on Friday, this time to "premium members" of the Australia-Israel Chamber of Commerce (AICC). Being an invite-only lunch, the briefing is not flagged on the "coming up" section of the RBA website. How do I know about it? Only because I am on the AICC mailing list. Mr Lowe defended his appearance at the Barrenjoey lunch, saying nothing untoward occurred and telling a parliamentary committee "I can't live in a bubble". Mr Lowe told that committee that the bank would extend blackout periods to ensure that he didn't make such appearances between rates decisions and major policy statements from the RBA. That will not be the case this week, and Mr Lowe will deliver an address open to the media tomorrow morning at the Morgan Stanley Australia Summit, which the ABC will cover. The RBA does hold regular background and off the record conversations with market participants and the media, including the ABC. However, appearances at closed "members only" events are perhaps a poor look after a major review into the bank urged greater public transparency around its decision-making.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA governor Lowe to make 'invite-only boardroom lunch' appearance

(AICC)
Mr Lowe defended his appearance at the Barrenjoey lunch, saying nothing untoward occurred and
telling a parliamentary committee "I can't live in a bubble"
Mr Lowe told that committee that the bank would extend blackout periods to ensure that he didn't make such appearances between rates decisions and major policy statements from the RBA.
That will not be the case this week, and
Mr Lowe will deliver an address open to the media tomorrow morning at the Morgan Stanley Australia Summit
, which the ABC will cover.
The RBA does hold regular background and off the record conversations with market participants and the media, including the ABC.
However, appearances at closed "members only" events are perhaps a poor look after
a major review into the bank urged greater public transparency
around its decision-making.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket has opened lower, down 0.7% to 7,168 points as of 10:15am AEST. It's fallen by more than investors had expected, and has reversed a majority of its 1% gain at the close of trade yesterday. Baby Bunting has taken a hit after downgrading its profit forecast by almost half, citing a slowdown in consumer spending despite the recent commencement of a sale. So far they're down by 19.1% to $1.78. Market operator ASX has also fallen, as it holds an investor day which outlines its plans for the coming five years. The top five performers so far are: A2 Milk Company +7% Auckland International Airport +0.5% BlueScope Steel +0.4% AGL Energy +0.3% Ansell +0.04% The bottom five performers so far are: ASX Ltd -5.9% ARB Corporation -1.6% Bapcor Ltd -1.4% Aristocrat Leisure -1.5% Arena Reit No 1 -1.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower as Baby Bunting forecasts slump in profits

children.content: The Australian sharemarket has opened lower, down 0.7% to 7,168 points as of 10:15am AEST.
It's fallen by more than investors had expected, and has reversed a majority of its 1% gain at the close of trade yesterday.
Baby Bunting
has taken a hit after downgrading its profit forecast by almost half, citing a slowdown in consumer spending despite the recent commencement of a sale. So far they're down by 19.1% to $1.78.
Market operator ASX has also fallen, as it holds an investor day which outlines its plans for the coming five years.
The top five performers so far are:
A2 Milk Company +7%
Auckland International Airport +0.5%
BlueScope Steel +0.4%
AGL Energy +0.3%
Ansell +0.04%
The bottom five performers so far are:
ASX Ltd -5.9%
ARB Corporation -1.6%
Bapcor Ltd -1.4%
Aristocrat Leisure -1.5%
Arena Reit No 1 -1.3%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Do the RBA even care that they are crippling Australians with these rate rises? - Steve. Hey Steve, you're certainly not alone in feeling this way. RBA governor Philip Lowe even made a note of this when he appeared at Senate Estimates last week, and said the experiences of Australians were something they discussed in their monthly board meetings. But he said they had a tough job in having to stop rising inflation, which is hurting Australians, on top of increasing interest rates. "I know higher interest rates are unpopular, they're hurting people, it's very tough," he said. "In our board discussions, we look at the alternative. "The end result [if inflation was not controlled] would be higher interest rates, more pain and higher unemployment. "It's not a scare campaign, but we want people to understand its serious. " Every single family is feeling those cost-of-living pressures, and that's because over the past year prices went up 7% and we have got to stop that. "I know what we're doing is painful and it's very difficult for many people bit it's necessary."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Does the RBA care they're 'crippling Australians' with rate rises?

children.content: Do the RBA even care that they are crippling Australians with these rate rises?
- Steve
Hey Steve, you're certainly not alone in feeling this way.
RBA governor Philip Lowe
even made a note of this when he appeared at Senate Estimates last week, and said the experiences of Australians were something they discussed in their monthly board meetings.
But he said they had a tough job in having to stop rising inflation, which is hurting Australians, on top of increasing interest rates.
"I know higher interest rates are unpopular, they're hurting people, it's very tough," he said.
"In our board discussions, we look at the alternative.
"The end result [if inflation was not controlled] would be higher interest rates, more pain and higher unemployment.
"It's not a scare campaign, but we want people to understand its serious.
Every single family is feeling those cost-of-living pressures, and that's because over the past year prices went up 7%
and we have got to stop that.
"I know what we're doing is painful and it's very difficult for many people bit it's necessary."
